turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: I'm fine.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Ok...

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You know, I was thinking... All that stuff father Seamus said...about discord, distrust... we're doing all right, aren't we?  You don't have any doubts about me, do you?

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: Should I...

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: No.  You two are the most important things in my life.  I don't ever want to lose you.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: You don't think I know?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Know what?

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: Do you think I'm a fool?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: Nothing's changed, has it. You still want to deceive me?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Maura, what is this!

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: We're not going.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Not going!  Are you out of your mind?!  Wait!

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: We'll destroy you...destroy all of you!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: No...  NO!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Maura!

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: What's happening!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Are you all right?

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: I'm ok.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: You're bleeding.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I'm all right...

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: Not at all.  I'm just trying to put together all the evidence, to determine what it could possibly be.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: Well that's what we're here for. I mean -

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: We don't know.

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: I could see if I detect the presence of something.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: I think we should do it.

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: We're usually successful in detecting the source of most problems.  Unfortunately.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: What do you mean, unfortunately?

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: We usually find nothing.  We've debunked many a reported haunting. About ninety five percent of the cases had some technical explanation.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: What about the other five percent?

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: Where is your daughter?  She might be able to give us some information.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: She's at school.  We've tried not to upset her more than she's been.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: Ok, so we have a...presence.  What do we do about it?

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: If we have a troubled spirit here, we have to find out why it's troubled.

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: I'm not sure, but I can check.  Did the events start before or after you discovered this?

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: Before.

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: You've done your homework, Mrs. South.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: Maura.

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: Maura.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: Yeah, they told us this was the best.

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: I'm hungry enough to eat a horse.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: You'll have to settle for turkey.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: Is white meat all right for you, Mr. Shea?

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: White meat will be fine...

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: You must be a Londrigan.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: Yes, I am.

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: ...at her request.  She was a very religious woman.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: Oh, that's nice...

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: May I come in?

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: Thank you.  I believe she would have wanted it.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: Did you know her very well?

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: She attended the church for years. A dear woman, it was sad to see her decline so rapidly.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: It was a shame.

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: In her later years she would often get very disoriented being alone here.  She would call me, and I would come by.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: Well it's nice that you were there for her.

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: I took pity on the poor woman. This house is too big for one person to live alone in...

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: Your daughter's been taken.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: What!

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: I'm going to need some blood.  It must be from a woman.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: The blood of a woman is birth, life. It is part of the ceremony. Seamus offers up the pin - Maura waits a beat, then takes it -

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: Now you must listen to me. This force is like a parasite, or a virus. It feeds on doubt, suspicion, discord... you must clear your mind as we reach out for her.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: So what should we do, father?

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: Go ahead.  I believe right now she may hear you.

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: Aubrey?  It's mommy.

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: Concentrate!  She can hear you!

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: Come back to us honey, don't be afraid!

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: She's coming back.  Keep talking!

turns.speaker: MAURA
turns.text: Come back to us honey!

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: You must be the new tenants.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: And you...are?

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: My name is Father Seamus.  I'm from Holy Rood church.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: How can I help you?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What was she afraid of?

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: Well, I believe her mind was playing tricks on her, God rest her soul.  She would hear things, see things...

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Did you have dinner, father?  We have plenty.

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: Well thank you for the offer,  But I really have to go.

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: I hope everything works out for you, and you find happiness in your new home.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: Perhaps I'll see you in church.

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: Well there's no time like the present.  Good night.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: We'll never know for sure.

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: Hopefully the whole sad chapter is over.  And everyone, including your family, will find peace. WILL I just want to...thank all of you, for everything you've done for us.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: This isn't happening...

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: The amulet...

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What...amulet?

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: Did you remove anything in the cellar!

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: I said nothing before, for fear you wouldn't believe me.  I've been here before to cast evil from this house.  The amulet is a guard against evil, blessed in countless rituals.   It is an ancient ceremony of the early Catholic church, a ceremony whose secrets are all but lost.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: So what does that have to do with Aubrey!  Where is she!

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: We must return it, if you want your daughter back.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What are you getting at!

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: I said nothing before, for fear you wouldn't believe me.  I've exorcised forces from this house. Eliza knew, she was there.  It wants another soul, the one we've taken away. We must weaken it!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: How long will it take!

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: It will not take long...

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: Keep talking!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: It can't hurt you if you're not afraid Aubrey.  Think about us. We're here for you, we love you...

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: The rain is letting up.

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: Yes it is. Will and Seamus look at each other -

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I don't know what happened... and I don't know what you did...

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: I didn't do anything...God saved her...

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What's going to happen?

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: I wish I had an answer.  Evil is powerful, more so every day it seems.  But I believe the worst for you and for this house is behind us.

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: Take care of the girl.  Take care of your family.  They are important.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Yes, they are.

turns.speaker: SEAMUS
turns.text: Well, you know where to reach me. The church is a stone's throw away if you want to come to mass.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: We'll be there.

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: No.  But I'm a clairvoyant.  I can sometimes talk to unhappy spirits inhabiting a certain place.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: Well it all depends on how much money you want to spend.  A standard visit would run you about fifty pounds.  That would include myself and an assistant.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: And what would you do?

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: Well, we could bring in special equipment, monitors, sound devices, things like that.

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: Looks like we have some animal hairs in here.  Maybe some kind of a rodent.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: So is that what all this is? Someone have a problem with us living here?

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: Not someone.  Something. I've never felt a presence that strong before.

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: Do you have any other physical evidence, that we can look at?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Not really.  Oh, wait a minute.

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: Where did you find this?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: It was nailed to the cellar wall.

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: I see some faint lettering.  It appears to be the...Runic alphabet?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Runic?

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: Do you mind if I borrow it?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Not at all, if it can help.

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: There's something in there.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: There's something through that wall!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Well what is it!

turns.speaker: SHEA
turns.text: I don't know!  Trust what I'm saying, we have to open this wall!

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: I mean hardly any thigh.  I'm telling you, Joey; shorter skirt, more lift on the leg-cross ... and you're made.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: What, you think I'm kidding?  I guarantee it.  An inch more flank.  Boys upstairs get hot.  Bingo, you're an anchor-woman.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Jesus Christ ...

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: C'mon, Joey.  I'm just trying to help you hit a home run here.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Yeah?  Well, you just struck out.  It may be a surprise to you, Brad, but I want to do it the right way.  Not tight skirts.  Tight stories.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Right.  Like last night's doozie.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: I know what I saw.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: And I believe what you say.  But this is TV.  No pictures, no story.

turns.speaker: BRAD
turns.text: Not on station time.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: No.  Not on station time.  My story.  My time.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: I know.  I know.  But it's just so ... neat, isn't it?  The first gig that isn't cute kids or diet gurus and it's taken away from me.

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: Yeah, well like you said - it's a mystery.  But that's all it is. Mystery.  Not malice.  What, you think the station paid off every accident victim in the city to ... ?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Better hurry, Doc.  A real story.  With a real reporter.

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: Joey ....  Look, you wanna ride?  I can go by your place.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: You'd lose the money-shots.  No.  I'll catch a bus.  Or a cab.  Don't worry about it.  Go.

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: OK.  Be careful.  And lighten up.  Story of your life could be right round the corner.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: That is the story of my life.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: You wanted a story.  You got it.  Turn on the TV now.  And then get your ass down here ...  ...

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Doc?  ...  Doc ... Hello?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Wait ... wait.  You ... you have to help me.  I don't understand.  Am I dreaming this?

turns.speaker: ELLIOTT
turns.text: You have to help me.  You will understand.  And no, you're not dreaming.  Do you know where we are?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: It's ... I don't know.  First World War, right?

turns.speaker: ELLIOTT
turns.text: Correct.  The fields of France.  And many dead flowers ... Oh.  Forgive me. My name was Spenser.  Elliott Spenser. Captain.

turns.speaker: ELLIOTT
turns.text: Well done.  Brave girl.  You've probably never shaken hands with a ghost before, am I right?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Captain Spenser.  Elliott.  I ... What the Hell is going on?

turns.speaker: ELLIOTT
turns.text: Hell is precisely what is going on, Joey.  And we have to stop it.  I because of a special obligation, you because you're the only person who can help. And because you know what is right, and just, and true.  Will you walk with me a while?

turns.speaker: ELLIOTT
turns.text: The war pulled poetry out of some of us. Others it affected differently.  This is me a few years later.  We're in India, by the way, and it's 1921.  I was like many survivors. Lost souls with nothing left to believe in but gratification. We'd seen God fail, you see.  So many dead.  For us God, too, fell at Flanders.  We adjusted to the loss.  And if we mourned, we mourned in silence. Thousands drank themselves to death. Others went further.  I went further.  I thought I was a lost soul.  But, until this frozen moment, I didn't even know what the phrase meant.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: And what is ... this frozen moment?

turns.speaker: ELLIOTT
turns.text: The cusp of my life.  What I was, what I am, what I will be ... past, present, future, all bound here at this timeless moment of decision.  I was an explorer of forbidden vices and pleasures. Opening the Box was my final act of exploration, of discovery.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: And what did you discover?

turns.speaker: ELLIOTT
turns.text: Something bad.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: And why are you back?  Why are we here?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Kirsty Cotton.  Yes.  But ... if your soul was freed, why are you back?

turns.speaker: ELLIOTT
turns.text: Because - monster as I was - I was bound by Laws.  The protocol of Hell.  The Box had to be opened to let me out.  The truly innocent were safe.  That's no longer true.  The shell of the beast has been fleshed.  What I was is out there, Joey.  In your world.  Unbound. Unstoppable.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: What will he do?  What does he want?

turns.speaker: ELLIOTT
turns.text: He'll do what he does best.  But he'll do it unfettered.  He wants to walk the Earth forever, indulging his taste for all the myriad subtleties of human suffering.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: What can we do?

turns.speaker: ELLIOTT
turns.text: I like you, Joey.  You ask all the right questions.  There is something we can do but it will require great courage.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: I don't know ...

turns.speaker: ELLIOTT
turns.text: Joey, you walked through your window from one reality to another.  You're stronger than you think.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Then tell me what to do.

turns.speaker: ELLIOTT
turns.text: This is his first night on Earth.  He wants to close the door behind him. Like all Lieutenants, he covets command. There's a gateway to Hell through which he can be taken back.  He has to destroy it.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: So where is it?

turns.speaker: ELLIOTT
turns.text: Your apartment.

turns.speaker: ELLIOTT
turns.text: The Box, Joey.  He wants the Box.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: It was off the statue.  In the club.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: What happened to him?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Hold on.  Hold on, please.  I need talk to you.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: It's nothing to do with me.  I wasn't even with him.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Look, lady!  I told you!  It's not my problem!  I was just there!

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Under The Underground.  Can I like GO now?!

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Under the Underground?  What's that? Where is ...

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Uh-huh?

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Uh ... Hi!  Is this ... er ... Joanne Summerskill?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Joey.  Yeah, who is this?

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: You like ... left me a card?  At the club?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Right.  Right!

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Right ... So ... Well, what do you want?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: I want to talk to you.  We met ... now, listen, don't hang up, OK? ... We met at the hospital last night.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Oh yeah.  Yeah.  Well ... Look, I'll make a deal with you ... My boyfriend threw me out, right?  I'll trade you. You give me couch-space.  I'll give you talk.  OK?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Yeah.  Sure.  You mean ... tonight?

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Of course tonight.  Is that a problem? Like, if you've got a guy there or something ...

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: No.  No.  It's fine.  Come now.  I was having bad dreams anyway.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: I put some decaf on.  Er ... make yourself comfortable.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Your dream.  You said you were having a bad dream.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Oh yeah ...

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: ... well, I've been having it for years. It's not a nightmare or anything.  It's ... well, I know what it is.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Why are you so interested?

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: No.  No, it's OK.  I ... It's my father.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Oh, right.  Did he used to ... ?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: God, no!  Nothing like that.  No, he died before I was born.  He died in Vietnam.  I never knew him.  Never met him.  We don't even know the details.  I dream of battlefields.  Of searching. Of trying to find out.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: That's great.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: No ... I mean, it's not like great about your dad or anything.  It's just I don't dream.  Never have.  ... Maybe it'd help if I slept sometime ... Just kidding ... No, so it's always neat for me to hear about dreams.  I'm jealous.  It's like everybody has another world except me. You know what I mean?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: I know what you're saying but ... Never? You've never had a dream?  No, you know, you do.  You must.  What you mean is you don't remember them.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Great.  Thanks.  You gonna have one?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: I'm trying to quit.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Oh, go on.  Have one.  Fuck it.  You think you're going to live forever?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Sorry.  It was my father's.  It's temperamental.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: It's okay.  It's just someone burned me once.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Oh.  You wanna talk about that stuff.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Yes I do.  Terri, something awful happened to that boy.  I have to find out what it was.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: But I don't know anything!  Really.  I just came out of the club and the kid was already in the street.  He ...

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Did you know him?

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: No.  I'd seen him in there a few times before.  He was just a punk.  I'd never like danced with him or anything. Anyway, he was a thief.  He must've taken it from the statue.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Taken what?

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: The thing!  He was lying there in the street, moaning.  But he pointed at it ... 22

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Wait a minute.  He was already ... wounded ... when you found him?

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Yeah!  That's what I'm saying!  And it was lying next to him.  And he pointed at it before he passed out and ...

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Wait.  Wait.  The chains.  Where did the chains come from?

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: That's what I'm trying to tell you! ...

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: I figured I'd make breakfast.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Right ... That's ... er ... that's nice of you, Terri.  Can I ask?  Is it always this ... exploratory?

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Ha!  I don't know yet.  First time. Kitchen virgin, that's me.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: I'll boil some water.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: I'll do it!

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: No!  No, that's OK.  I like to.  I love boiling water.  It's a specialty of mine.  Why don't you go watch cartoons?

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: This is great.  And it's yours?  You like own it?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: The bank owns it.  But I'm working on it.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Jeez, I've never owned anything.  I haven't even had a room of my own since I was fifteen years old.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: How have you ... ?

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Guys.  Sometimes friends.  Mostly guys.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Wow.  Lotta books.  You read all these?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: No.  I buy them to impress people.  Of course I've read them.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Cool.  I read a book once.  It was like all these people discovering who they used to be.  You know, like reincarnation?  It was really good.  You ever read that?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: I don't think so.  But it's a fascinating subject.  Did you ...

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: ... but it is good.  You know, over to the left, you can ...

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Who's that?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: I don't know his name ...  I saw the whole story.  A wounded bird was on his roof.  I could hear its cries from here. He went straight to it.  I couldn't've. I'd be frozen between pity and fear. But he wasn't.  Its pain spoke directly to him.  He picked it up.  Nursed it. Fed it.  And it got better.  Everyday he'd watch the pigeon.  Everyday the pigeon would watch him. I saw him learn. Learn that there was one more thing he had to do to make the rescue complete. And one day, just as afternoon became evening, he leaned over, opened the cage, and walked away.  Didn't look back.  But he heard the sound of its wings.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: And he still sits there?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Every day.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Maybe he thinks it'll come back.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: No.  He knows it won't.  It was his final act of love and part of him knows that and part of him doesn't yet.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: But I don't know what's going on.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Maybe not.  But you know more than I do. You know something about this box. Something about a statue?

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Yeah.  I found it.  I knew held like it and I figured ...

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Woah.  Wait a minute.  Who?  The kid?

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: No.  JP.  My last boyfriend?  He like owns the club.  You know?  You were there?  He bought the statue.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: That you found.  What do you mean you found it?

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: I was downtown looking for a ... a friend.  A guy I know.  Anyway, there was this store.  Like real old?  Lotsa weird shit in there.  I saw this statue. Pillar.  Thing.  I knew he'd love it. You've seen the club.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Would you know this store again?

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Sure.  Why?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: It's Saturday morning.  Let's go shopping.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Jesus.  Are you sure this is the street?

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Yeah.  Happening, isn't it?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: What on earth were you doing down here?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Terri?

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Buying some drugs, alright?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Oh, Terri ...

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: For somebody else, alright?  Not for me. I don't do that shit anymore.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Then you shouldn't even be around it. You know, it's ...

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Here!  Here!  Pull over!

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: What am I looking for?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: God knows.  Anything.  Contacts.  Clues.

turns.speaker: TERRI
turns.text: Joey ... ?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Help me pick 'em up, Terri.  I think the lady just made a sale.

turns.speaker: MAMA
turns.text: No.  Sorry.  Not interested.  Not for my customers.  Have you tried ...

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: No.  No, you don't understand.  We're not selling it.  It came from here.  We want ...

turns.speaker: MAMA
turns.text: Everything sold as is.  No guarantees. No returns.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: No.  We want ...

turns.speaker: MAMA
turns.text: I took back everything bought on a whim, I'd have no business.  I ...

turns.speaker: MAMA
turns.text: Never mind.  I'm glad it's gone.  Made the store feel strange.  Who'd make such a thing?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Fine.  Fine.  But can you tell us anything about it?

turns.speaker: MAMA
turns.text: It was part of a job-lot.  Some loony- bin they shut down.  Unclaimed stuff.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: What else came with it?  Anything still here?

turns.speaker: MAMA
turns.text: Sure.  Just papers, photos.  Stuff nobody'd ever want.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Can we see?

turns.speaker: MAMA
turns.text: You gonna buy?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: I don't know.  Maybe.

turns.speaker: MAMA
turns.text: Right at the back there.  Middle shelves.  Coupla folders.  Nice stuff. I'd do you a good price.

turns.speaker: JP
turns.text: Welcome. 38

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: You're JP Monroe, right?

turns.speaker: JP
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: And this is your club.  Great club.  I really love it here.  Great club.

turns.speaker: JP
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Thank you for the drink.  And the rose. Wow.  That's ... really nice.

turns.speaker: JP
turns.text: It's yours.  You won it.  It's a prize.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: A prize?  For what?

turns.speaker: JP
turns.text: You see, everyday I have my friend John here bring ...

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: The barman?  I thought he was called Rick?

turns.speaker: JP
turns.text: He's a barman.  Whatever.  Do you mind if I continue?

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: JP
turns.text: Everyday I have my friend Rick here bring a newly-cut red rose in with him and keep it behind the bar.  And I award it to a woman of exceptional beauty.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Oh come on.  There're lots of girls here who look better than ...

turns.speaker: JP
turns.text: Don't do that!  Don't put yourself down. If you have a quality, be proud of it...

turns.speaker: JP
turns.text: ... Let it define you.  Whatever it is. Most of the roses die behind the bar. This is the first I've given out for nearly a month.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: No.  Really?

turns.speaker: JP
turns.text: Yes really.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Wow.  Thank you.

turns.speaker: JP
turns.text: No.  Thank you.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Do you mind me talking about your stuff?

turns.speaker: JP
turns.text: Unh-unh.
